justification: The Methods section notes that depression was assessed "using Montgomery-Asberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS)."
The article lists "Beck's Depression Inventory (BDI; Beck et al., 1961)" among the questionnaires used to measure depression.
Participants also completed the "Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HAM-D; Hamilton, 1960)" to assess depressive symptoms.
Under Psychiatric questionnaires the study states that anxiety was measured with the "Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale (HAM-A; Hamilton, 1959)."
The paper reports use of "the trait version of State-Trait-Anxiety-Inventory (STAI; Spielberger, 1983)" for assessing trait anxiety.
Table 1 presents "STAI-S Score," indicating the state form of the STAI was used to gauge current (state) anxiety.
Worry was evaluated with the "Penn State Worry Questionnaire (PSWQ; Meyer et al., 1990)" according to the Psychiatric questionnaires section.
The same paragraph states that worry was also measured with "the Worry Domains Questionnaire (WDQ; Tallis et al., 1992)."

measured_by: Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV (SCID-I / SCID-II)
justification: Diagnostic status was determined "using the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV (SCID-I/SCID-II; First & Gibbon, 2004)."

measured_by: Dynamically Optimized Sequential Experimentation (DOSE) task – prospect-theoretic parameter ρ
justification: The DOSE task "allowed to estimate a 3-parameter risk preference model (loss aversion, risk aversion, and choice temperature)," with ρ indexing risk aversion.

measured_by: Dynamically Optimized Sequential Experimentation (DOSE) task – prospect-theoretic parameter λ
justification: In the same description, λ is identified as the parameter representing loss aversion derived from the DOSE task.

measured_by: Dynamically Optimized Sequential Experimentation (DOSE) task – choice temperature μ
justification: The Methods explain that μ from the DOSE task reflects "choice consistency," completing the three estimated preference parameters.
